Nicolas Maduro is the president of Venezuela since 2013 after the sudden demise of the former president, Chavez. Maduro was in the inner circle of Chavez and was already chosen. In the last 7 years, he has held with tight grip except for the latest coup attempt and another one in 2019.  To answer the question on Maduro's continuation after 01 June 2020, there are 3 possibilities: 1) Another successful coup - In the last 7 years, there were 2 coup attempts ( the two being consecutively in the last 2 years). Hence, the probability of executing another coup immediately and successfully is very low, but this choice can't be eliminated (20%).  2) Successful popular uprising - With economy in the doldrums and frustrated by the pandemic, this possibility may not be ruled out. However, there is a higher chance (40%). 3) Peaceful negotiation and democratic process - Maduro may announce a democratic election to improve the confidence and suppress any popular uprising (40%). Without any indicator for choices 1 and 3, the forecast depends upon the past occurrence and intuitive probabilities of each choice.
Economic underperformance has been a very poor predictor of regime change.

Ways Maduro would cease to be president: 1. Assassinated

3. Replaced by Guaido/someone else
4. Arrested/Detained 1.
The 2018 August 4th assassination attempt on Maduro shows that he is vulnerable. However, it would likely make him bolster his security and force more caution e.g. foiled plot in 2019 [1]. Furthermore, the COVID-19 crisis makes public appearances much less likely and limits opportunities (only contact with his inner circle). However, Venezuela reacted quickly to the outbreak and have fewer cases compared to their neighbors. The numbers must be taken with a grain of salt, but they definitely did act early and this may shorten its impact. However, second waves may become more likely if you recover faster than your neighbors. Civil unrest will rise as the conditions worsen, increasing the incentive for his assassination. 2.

During COVID-19 this is unlikely, especially during the peak stage of the outbreak. He recently consolidated some power with no repercussions (judicial killings). I spoke more about Guaido and opposition in another forecast. 4.
Last month the United States offered $15 million for any information leading to the arrest/conviction of Maduro. This does increase the chances of his arrest. It will also increase the chances of a member of Maduro's close circle giving intelligence or staging a coup, especially if his position becomes more precarious as the COVID-19 crisis, economic crisis and oil crisis plays out in full. The situation could become so bad that his most powerful domestic ally, the army, starts to defect and he is arrested or murdered in a violent coup. Overall, I believe Maduro's chances of remaining as president by June 1st are very high. The COVID-19 situation will place him behind closed doors for the majority of the next two months. Coups and desertions are catalysed by mass protests, and mass protests usually take time to become ‘mass’. However, this situation is unprecedented, and things may move very quickly. A few factors that support Maduro's reign through 1 June 2020: 1. Russian support. It is unlikely that the Russian government wants to lose faith by abandoning the Maduro regime less than a year after declaring support. More than mere support for the Maduro regime, the Russian government has geopolitical, financial, and military interests that mitigate against allowing the regime to collapse.  2. Collapse of a viable opposition. Several news outlets reported on 10 March that opposition protests, led by Juan Guaido, were easily contained. This suggests that no new divisions have appeared within the security apparatus, and that the opposition is being contained to a symbolic protest. Another element to consider here is that the outbreak of coronavirus gives the regime legitimate reasons for banning further large-scale protests, which could diminish any momentum they may have had been gathering.   A few factors that could tip the scales:  1. The price of oil. Government revenues depend on revenues from oil, and worldwide oil prices have plunged due to the price war between Russian, Saudi Arabia and the UAE. This will undoubtedly put pressure on Venezuela to find revenues to pay its security services. 2. The coronavirus. Two events in 2019 made it unlikely Maduro would leave power - first was when Russian military advisors arrived in March 2019 to support the Maduro regime; the second occurred when the Trump administration broke with NSA Bolton and saying that US military action was unlikely.  Sustained US pressure on the Maduro regime, particularly the threat of military intervention, appeared to be the only thing capable of forcing Maduro to consider stepping down from power.  Since then, many opposition lawmakers have fled the country or voted in favor of Maduro's Parliamentary candidate (under allegations of bribery).  US sanctions deny the Maduro regime the ability to freely sell Venezuelan oil in the international market as well as access to international financial institutions.  Ultimately, however, it is Maduro's monopoly on the use of force (with Russia's support) that keeps his regime in power.  If these dynamics remain unchanged, it is difficult to envision Maduro leaving power anytime soon.

How Maduro can cease to be the president of Venezuela before 1 June 2020 A.	Presidential election
It was the Presidential election 2018 that led to the current situation. Maduro won the election but the opposition and a significant part of the international community cried foul. Organising a new presidential election takes time. Nothing indicates that Maduro seeks an election. Even if an election is held it is not sure it would result in Maduro ceasing to be the president of Venezuela. No actor has the capacity to force a presidential election upon Maduro. Estimated likelihood 1%. B.	Coup d’etat
Attempts to rally the population and the military behind overthrowing Maduro has failed. The large majority of the military remains loyal to Maduro, even though there has been some defections. Forces from Cuba and Russia are on Venezuelan soil and supports Maduro. In theory a coup does not require a large military force, hence the capacity might exist as well as the intention. Of all the coup attempts in the world since 2010 few has been successful. Estimated likelihood 4%. C.	Death/ sickness
Maduro is 57 years old. He is overweight. Life expectancy in Venezuela is 74 years (2016). Cuba has sent doctors to Venezuela. That Maduro would become incapacitated or die from natural causes before 1 June 2020 is therefore unlikely. Estimated likelihood 1%. D.	Steps down voluntary
Maduro has shown no signs of wanting to step down as a sacrifice for the greater good. This might become an alternative, nevertheless, if he loses the support of Russia, Cuba or from the military top brass. Hence, there are actors with the capacity to force him to step down, but the intention is lacking. Estimated likelihood 3%. E.	Foreign military intervention
Most of the neighbouring countries have ruled out intervening to overthrow Maduro.  Planning a military intervention takes time, and the only foreign power with the power to oust Maduro, USA, has an administration with a policy of reducing the global military footprint. Estimated likelihood 1%. Conclusion
Alternatives A-E add up to a 10% likelihood that Maduro will cease to be president of Venezuela before 1 June 2020. References:

I am starting this forecast with a base rate of ~12%.  Venezuela has had 15 Presidents since 1953.  Two have been deposed.  Given recent trends in the world over the past 20 or so years, it typically takes foreign intervention of some form to depose a dictator.  Currently, 54 countries recognize Juan Guaidó while China, Cuba, Iran, Russia, Syria, and Turkey support Maduro.  Of note, Putin has deepened Russian involvement in Venezuela to keep Maduro in power (https://www.atlanticcouncil.org/in-depth-research-reports/report/russias-intervention-in-venezuela-whats-at-stake/), which decreases the likelihood of Maduro being ousted.  The U.S. would need to do more than sanctions to oust Maduro, and the US is unlikely to do so, especially with the upcoming elections.  As a result, I'm decreasing the forecast to 9%. Internally, Venezuela's economy is in shambles with massive inflation.  Maduro still has the support of the military but worsening economic conditions may cause significant backlash among the populace.  If Maduro loses the support of the military, the probability he will be deposed will increase.  If the current status quo remains the same until June, it is unlikely Maduro will cease to be president by then.  I will also be keeping an eye on increases in popular support for Guaidó.

This question may require additional clarification since more than 50 governments currently recognize the leader of the opposition Juan Guaido as the President of Venezuela.   This question is appears to asking if Maduro will lose control of the central portion of the military/government that allows him to use state resources.  Thus far external pressure (economic) has not been able to shake Maduro out of the capital; however, in a country that has been destabilized and fractured like Venezuela change can come quickly.   Most press reports indicate the population that is capable of leaving has probably left (about 3 million over the last few years).  Those who remain continue to persist in a semi-stateless environment relying on external sources for cash, trade, and security.  There is little incentive for most of these elements to actually seek to control the government.  Internal opposition led by Guaido wants to take control, but they appear to have little in the way of means to achieve that end.  The question devolves to - how long can Maduro continue to pay supporters or how many supporters fear for their own security if Maduro is deposed?   Maduro has used state resources and will continue to use those resources to pay for his supporters.  Ceasing payments / an inability to pay before June appears very unlikely.   Supporters who fear for themselves will support to the end... The question is how many?  The recent activities at the national assembly grounds seems to indicate strength of support among his military personnel has not waned to a critical point.  He had enough personnel to bar the opposition members from entering the assembly and allowed what the European Union's spokesperson called unacceptable.

Few dictators in oil rich states under U.S. pressure have been deposed. One required direct U.S. military intervention (Saddam Hussein), and the other was, at a minimum, greatly facilitated by U.S./NATO military intervention (Muammar Gaddafi). The conditions for such an intervention do not exist (e.g., threat to U.S. energy supply, well-publicized humanitarian crisis, Russian/Chinese acquiescence). The base rate I'm choosing, therefore, is close to zero.  Events over the last several months do not argue for moving far from zero: Maduro’s endurance through international pressure and recognition of the opposition; continued control the military, judiciary, and security apparatus, showing no clear indicators of near term fracture; most recently, Maduro's move to take control of the legislature on 6 Jan 2020.
